text: Hey everyone, welcome to this week's
news and community spotlights. The
Unreal Engine 5.6 preview is now
available. Download now on the Epic
Games Launcher, GitHub, and Linux. You
can also check out the public road map.
If you're interested in learning more
about what's coming with 5.6, tune in to
State of Unreal, which will broadcast
live from Unreal Fest Orlando on June
3rd.
These days, everybody seems to be
pondering the impact that AI will have
on the design and development of
interactive entertainment. Although this
is a hot topic, indie developer Chump
Squad's president and primary developer
Gwen Frey has been exploring this
concept for quite some time. In fact,
her exploration of these ideas dates
back to her loneliest days in isolation
during the pandemic. However, rather
than wrestling with the unknown, when
gave herself an outlet by creating the
unique and satirical Lab Rat, which
presents itself as a puzzle game
developed using machine learning
technology and showcases the hilarious
flaws that result from such methods. So,
what is the game really all about? And
why did Gwen and the small team at Chump
Squad choose Unreal Engine 5 to achieve
their goals? We tested Gwen with a few
questions to find out. If you're
interested in seeing the full interview,
you can do so at unrealeng
engine.com/feed. We're excited to
announce that our UEIE education team is
launching a new beginner course that
will be available on the Unreal Academy
platform, the Epic Developer Community,
and YouTube. Take your first steps
towards game development with our 2.5D
game course. Designed for beginners and
taught by industry experts, this
comprehensive course will equip you with
the knowledge and skills needed to
develop a game in Unreal Engine. The
course comprises of seven mini courses
and covers key topics to get started
with the UEE using 2D assets and
plugins. You'll learn the foundational
skills to develop a game, including
engine navigation, blueprint
integration, plug-in management, working
with materials, and world building. By
the end, you'll be ready to create your
own experiences from start to finish.
All you need is a passion for gaming to
take this course. Creativity and problem
solving skills are a plus. Ready to
learn? Take the first steps
today. Join your local chapter to grow,
learn, and be inspired. Here are some
upcoming events to check
out. Now, let's get into the amazing
community spotlights for this week. An
incredible personal project by Guame Hec
based on the concept art of GXY. Moss
Gardens was aimed at exploring new
workflows and shaders specifically
working on transitioning from urban to
organic environments while tackling the
impressive task of creating all assets,
materials, shaders, tools, and textures
on their own. They created a detailed
biome setpiece with multiple points of
interest and navigation elements that
feel natural and immersive. Everything
you see was built and rendered in Unreal
Engine 5.2. It was handcrafted with no
AI scans or 3D library assets used in
its
creation. Based on the concept of tow
Anderson by Jean Pao is a character
project that pays special attention to
expression through posture and
environmental storytelling integrating
details that enhance the narrative of
the piece even at a quick glance.
Showcasing impressive texturing and
shading methods, the juxtaposition of
Anderson and his wife and the extremely
varied approaches to both left us
wanting to know more about the world
they were crafted for.
The project by Philip Sparak is a
large-scale environment project that
showcases a massive city that is both
fully modular and fully real-time. It
was created in Unreal Engine 5 using key
features like world partition, nanite
and lumen. Prefabs were assembled using
PLA's in world petition map, combining a
whopping 1500 unique static meshes, 25
handcrafted city blocks, 29 unique
building prefabs with their own
interiors, 44 modular road prefabs, and
26 arrangement prefabs to create a
sprawling metropolis with all original
materials and blueprints. This was a
truly impressive undertaking, and we're
blown away by the results. What do you
think? You can find out more from all of
these artists on their respective art
stations. That's it for this week's news
and community spotlights. Thank you so
much for watching and we'll see you next
time.
